text: This is a list of all Internet Relay Chat commands from IETF RFCs 1459 and 2812. Most IRC clients need commands to have a slash ("/") before the command. Angle brackets ("<" and ">") mean what's placed in the secondary field, not a literal part of the command. Settings encapsulated in square brackets ("[" and "]") are optional and override the command's defaults. ==User commands== Command Syntax Function Defined ADMIN `ADMIN []` Asks the server for information about the administrator of the server ,If target is not used, the current server is used. RFC 1459 AWAY `AWAY []` GIves the server a message to send in reply to a PRIVMSG to the user. Removes away status if is not used. RFC 1459 CONNECT `CONNECT [ []]` (RFC 1459) `CONNECT []` ( RFC 2812) Tells the server (or the current server, if is not used) to connect to on port . This command can normally only be used by IRC Operators. DIE `DIE` Tells the server to shut down. RFC 2812 ERROR `ERROR ` Use by servers to report errors to other servers. It is also used before ending client connections. RFC 1459 INFO `INFO []` Gives information about the server, or the current server if is not used The Information given includes the server's version, when it was compiled, the patch level, when it was started, and any other information which may be relevant. RFC 1459 INVITE `INVITE ` Invites to the channel . does not have to exist. If it does, only members of the channel can invite other clients. If the channel mode i is set, only channel operators may invite other clients. RFC 1459 ISON `ISON ` Asks the server to see if the clients in the list are on the network. The server returns the nicknames that are on the network. If none of the clients are on the network the server returns an empty list. RFC 1459 JOIN `JOIN []` Makes the client join the channels in the list Passwords can be used in the list . If the channel(s) do not exist, they will be created. RFC 1459 KICK `KICK []` Removes from . This command may only be issued by channel operators. RFC 1459 KILL `KILL ` Removes from the network. This command may only be used by IRC operators. RFC 1459 Other website `LINKS [ []]` Lists all server links matching on , or the current server if is not used. RFC 1459 LIST `LIST [ []]` Lists all channels on the server. If the list is given, it will return the channel topics. If is given, the command will be sent to for evaluation. RFC 1459 LUSERS `LUSERS [ []]` Returns statistics about the size of the network. If used with no arguments, the statistics will be about the entire network. If is given, it will return only statistics about the masked subset of the network. If is given, the command will be sent to for evaluation. RFC 2812 MODE `MODE (user)` `MODE []` The MODE command is has two uses. It can be used to set both user and channel modes. RFC 1459 MOTD `MOTD []` Returns the message of the day on or the current server if it is not stated. RFC 2812 NAMES `NAMES []` (RFC 1459) `NAMES [ []]` ( RFC 2812) Returns a list of who is on the list of , by channel name. If is not used, all users are shown,. They are grouped by channel name with all users who are not on a channel being shown as part of channel "*". If is specified, the command is sent to for evaluation. RFC 1459 NICK `NICK []` (RFC 1459) `NICK ` ( RFC 2812) Allows a client to change their IRC nickname. Hopcount is for use between servers to say how far away a nickname is from its home server. RFC 1459 NOTICE `NOTICE ` Similar to PRIVMSG, but automatic replies are never sent in reply to NOTICE messages. RFC 1459 OPER `OPER ` Identifies a user as an IRC operator on that server/network. RFC 1459 PART `PART ` Causes a user to leave the channels in the list . RFC 1459 PASS `PASS ` Sets a connection password. This command must be sent before the NICK/USER registration combination. RFC 1459 PING `PING []` Tests a connection. A PING message results in a PONG reply. If is given, the message is sent to it. RFC 1459 PONG `PONG []` This command is a reply to the PING command. It works in much the same way. RFC 1459 PRIVMSG `PRIVMSG ` Sends to . The target is usually a user or channel. RFC 1459 QUIT `QUIT []` Disconnects the user from the server. RFC 1459 REHASH `REHASH` Causes the server to re-read and re- process its configuration file(s). This command can only be sent by IRC Operators. RFC 1459 RESTART `RESTART` Restarts a server. It may only be sent by IRC Operators. RFC 1459 SERVICE `SERVICE ` Registers a new service on the network. RFC 2812 SERVLIST `SERVLIST [ []]` Lists the services currently on the network. RFC 2812 SERVER `SERVER ` Used to tell a server that the other end of a new connection is a server. This message is also used to send server data over whole network. says how many hops (server connections) away is. has information about the server. RFC 1459 SQUERY `SQUERY ` Same as PRIVMSG except it must be sent to a service. RFC 2812 SQUIT `SQUIT ` Causes to quit the network. RFC 1459 STATS `STATS []` Returns statistics about the current server, or if it is given. RFC 1459 SUMMON `SUMMON []` (RFC 1459 `SUMMON [ []]` ( RFC 2812) Sends a message to users on the same host as asking them to join IRC. RFC 1459 TIME `TIME []` Gives the local time on the current server, or if specified. RFC 1459 TOPIC `TOPIC []` Used to get the channel topic on . If is given, it sets the channel topic to . If channel mode +t is set, only a channel operator may set the topic. RFC 1459 TRACE `TRACE []` Trace a path across the IRC network to a specific server or client, in a similar method to traceroute. RFC 1459 USER `USER ` (RFC 1459) `USER ` ( RFC 2812) This command is used at the beginning of a connection to specify the username, hostname, real name and initial user modes of the connecting client. may contain spaces, and thus must be prefixed with a colon. RFC 1459 RFC 2812 USERHOST `USERHOST [ ...]` Returns a list of information about the nicknames specified. RFC 1459 USERS `USERS []` Returns a list of users and information about those users in a format similar to the UNIX commands who, rusers and finger. RFC 1459 VERSION `VERSION []` Returns the version of , or the current server if omitted. RFC 1459 WALLOPS `WALLOPS ` Sends to all operators connected to the server (RFC 1459), or all users with user mode 'w' set ( RFC 2812). RFC 1459 WHO `WHO [ ["o"]]` Returns a list of users who match . If the flag "o" is given, the server will only return information about IRC Operators. RFC 1459 WHOIS `WHOIS [] ` Returns information about the comma- separated list of nicknames masks . If is given, the command is forwarded to it for processing. RFC 1459 WHOWAS `WHOWAS [ []]` Returns information about a nickname that is no longer in use (due to client disconnection, or nickname changes). If given, the server will return information from the last times the nickname has been used. If is given, the command is forwarded to it for processing. In RFC 2812, can be a comma-separated list of nicknames. RFC 1459 ==Notes== ==Related pages== * Internet Relay Chat * IRCd * IRCX * Server ==References== ==Bibliography== * * ==Further reading== * * * * Commands Category:Computer-related lists
title: List of Internet Relay Chat commands
